0;49;0a9c1f1a54aed7e0815c4e989a407ea7c2e936a54df73f3b42234c4417d00870;posted_link;r/Physics;http://arstechnica.com/science/news/2010/05/quantum-teleportation-achieved-over-ten-miles-of-free-space.ars?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=rss;['c6llq'];['Vailhem'];[1274423874.0];['Quantum teleportation achieved over ten miles of free space'];[nan];2010-05-19;Casey Johnston;Quantum teleportation achieved over ten miles of free space;"Quantum teleportation has achieved a new milestone or
column2: should we say
column3: a new ten-milestone: scientists have recently had success teleporting information between photons over a free space distance of nearly ten miles
column4: an unprecedented length. The researchers who have accomplished this feat note that this brings us closer to communicating information without needing a traditional signal
column5: and that the ten miles they have reached could span the distance between the surface of the earth and space.

column1: As we've explained before
column2: ""quantum teleportation"" is quite different from how many people imagine teleportation to work. Rather than picking one thing up and placing it somewhere else
column3: quantum teleportation involves entangling two things
column4: like photons or ions
column5: so their states are dependent on one another and each can be affected by the measurement of the other's state.

column1: When one of the items is sent a distance away
column2: entanglement ensures that changing the state of one causes the other to change as well
column3: allowing the teleportation of quantum information
column4: if not matter. However
column5: the distance particles can be from each other has been limited so far to a number of meters.

column1: Teleportation over distances of a few hundred meters has previously only been accomplished with the photons traveling in fiber channels to help preserve their state. In this particular experiment
column2: researchers maximally entangled two photons using both spatial and polarization modes and sent the one with higher energy through a ten-mile-long free space channel. They found that the distant photon was still able to respond to changes in state of the photon they held onto even at this unprecedented distance.

column1: However
column2: the long-distance teleportation of a photon is only a small step towards developing applications for the procedure. While photons are good at transmitting information
column3: they are not as good as ions at allowing manipulation
column4: an advancement we'd need for encryption. Researchers were also able to maintain the fidelity of the long-distance teleportation at 89 percent— decent enough for information
column5: but still dangerous for the whole-body human teleportation that we're all looking forward to.";2182;['c0qgtgd'

column1: 1;1077;9b95d8115a3397140d17c3dd01a6a153a137c85ed13485fe7f152f8bee1d4eaf;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://www.space.com/google-invents-time-crystal;['prk79l'];['EricFromOuterSpace'];[1632098711.0];"[""Researchers working in partnership with Google may have just used the tech giant's quantum computer to create a completely new phase of matter—a time crystal. With the ability to forever cycle between two states without ever losing energy
column2: time crystals seem to dodge the 2nd law of thermodynamics.""]";[nan];2021-09-18;Ben Turner;Otherworldly 'time crystal' made inside Google quantum computer could change physics forever;"Researchers working in partnership with Google may have just used the tech giant's quantum computer to create a completely new phase of matter (opens in new tab) — a time crystal.

column1: With the ability to forever cycle between two states without ever losing energy
column2: time crystals dodge one of the most important laws of physics — the second law of thermodynamics (opens in new tab)
column3: which states that the disorder
column4: or entropy
column5: of an isolated system must always increase. These bizarre time crystals remain stable
column7: despite existing in a constant state of flux.

column1: According to a research article posted July 28 to the preprint database arXiv (opens in new tab)
column2: scientists were able to create the time crystal for roughly 100 seconds using qubits (quantum computing's version of the traditional computer bit) inside the core of Google's Sycamore quantum processor.

column1: The existence of this weird new matter phase
column2: and the entirely new realm of physical behaviors it reveals
column3: is incredibly exciting to physicists
column4: especially as time crystals were only first predicted to exist just nine years ago.

column1: This was a big surprise
column2: Curt von Keyserlingk
column3: a physicist at the University of Birmingham in the U.K. who was not involved in the study
column4: told Live Science. ""If you asked someone 30
column5: 20 or maybe even 10 years ago
column6: they would not have expected this.""

column1: Time crystals are fascinating objects to physicists because they essentially sidestep the second law of thermodynamics
column2: one of the most ironclad laws in physics. It states that entropy (a rough analog for the amount of disorder in a system) always increases. If you want to make something more ordered
column3: you need to put more energy into it.

column1: This tendency for disorder to grow explains a lot of things
column2: such as why it's easier to stir ingredients into a mixture than it is to separate them out again
column3: or why headphone cords get so tangled in pants' pockets. It also sets the arrow of time
column4: with the past universe always more ordered than the present; watching a video in reverse
column5: for instance
column6: is likely to look strange to you primarily because you're witnessing the counterintuitive reversal of this entropic flow.(opens in new tab)

column1: Time crystals don't follow this rule. Instead of slowly approaching thermal equilibrium — ""thermalizing"" so that their energy or temperature is equally distributed throughout their surroundings
column2: they get stuck between two energy states above that equilibrium state
column3: cycling back and forth between them indefinitely.

column1: To explain how deeply unusual this behavior is
column2: von Keyserlingk said to picture a sealed box filled with coins before being shaken a million times. As the coins ricochet from
column3: and bounce around
column4: each other
column5: they ""become more and more chaotic
column6: exploring all of the sorts of configurations that they can explore"" until the shaking stops
column7: and the box is opened to reveal the coins in a random configuration
column8: with roughly half of the coins facing up and half facing down. We can expect to see this random
column10: half-down endpoint regardless of the way we first arranged the coins in the box.

column1: Inside the ""box"" of Google's Sycamore
column2: we can view the quantum processor's qubits much like we would our coins. In the same way that the coins can be either heads or tails
column3: qubits can be either a 1 or a 0 — the two possible positions in a two-state system — or a weird mix of the probabilities of both states called a superposition. What's weird about time crystals
column4: von Keyserlingk says
column5: is that no amount of shaking
column6: or zapping from one state to another
column7: can move the time crystal's qubits into the lowest energy state
column8: which is a random configuration; they can only flip it from its starting state to its second state

column1: It just sort of flip-flops
column2: von Keyserlingk said. ""It doesn't end up looking random
column3: it just gets jammed stuck. It's like it remembers what it looked like initially
column4: and it repeats that pattern over time.""

column1: In this sense
column2: a time crystal is like a pendulum that never stops swinging.

column1: Even if you totally physically isolate a pendulum from the universe
column2: so there's no friction and no air resistance
column3: it will eventually stop. And that's because of the second law of thermodynamics
column4: Achilleas Lazarides
column5: a physicist at the University of Loughborough in the U.K. who was among the scientists to first discover the theoretical possibility of the new phase in 2015
column6: told Live Science. ""Energy starts out concentrated in the pendulum's center of mass
column7: but there's all of these internal degrees of freedom — like the ways the atoms (opens in new tab) can vibrate inside the rod — that it will eventually be transferred into.""

column1: In fact
column2: there's no way for a large-scale object to behave like a time crystal without sounding absurd
column3: because the only rules that enable time crystals to exist are the spooky and surreal rules that govern the world of the very small — quantum mechanics (opens in new tab).

column1: In the quantum world
column2: objects behave both like point particles and little waves at the same time
column3: with the magnitude of these waves in any given region of space representing the probability of finding a particle at that location. But randomness (such as random defects in a crystal's structure or a programmed randomness in the interaction strengths between qubits) can cause a particle's probability wave to cancel itself out everywhere apart from one very small region. Rooted in place
column4: unable to move
column5: change states or thermalize with its surroundings

column1: The researchers used this localization process as the foundation of their experiment. Using 20 strips of superconducting aluminum (opens in new tab) for their qubits
column2: the scientists programmed each one into one of two possible states. Then
column3: by blasting a microwave beam over the strips
column4: they were able to drive their qubits to flip states; the researchers repeated the experiment for tens of thousands of runs and stopped at different points to record the states their qubits were in. What they found was that their collection of qubits was flipping back and forth between only two configurations
column5: and the qubits weren't absorbing heat from the microwave beam either — they had made a time crystal.

column1: They also saw a key clue that their time crystal was a phase of matter. For something to be considered a phase
column2: it usually has to be very stable in the face of fluctuations. Solids will not melt if the temperatures (opens in new tab) around them vary slightly; neither will slight fluctuations cause liquids to evaporate or freeze suddenly. In the same way
column3: if the microwave beam used to flip the qubits between states was adjusted to be close to but slightly off from the exact 180 degrees needed for a perfect flip
column4: the qubits still nonetheless flipped to the other state.

column1: It's not the case that if you're not exactly at the 180 degrees you will scramble them
column2: Lazarides said. ""It [the time crystal] magically will always tip a bit in
column3: even if you're making slight mistakes.""

column1: Another hallmark of moving from one phase to another is the breaking of physical symmetries
column2: the idea that the laws of physics are the same for an object at any point in time or space. As a liquid
column3: the molecules in water follow the same physical laws at every point in space and in every direction
column4: but cool water down enough so that it transforms into ice and its molecules will pick regular points along a crystal structure — or lattice — to arrange themselves across. Suddenly
column5: the water molecules have preferred points in space to occupy
column6: and they leave the other points empty — the spatial symmetry of the water has been spontaneously broken.

column1: In much the same way that ice becomes a crystal in space by breaking with spatial symmetry
column2: time crystals become crystals in time by breaking with time symmetry. At first
column3: before their transformation into the time crystal phase
column4: the row of qubits will experience a continuous symmetry between all moments in time. But the periodic cycle of the microwave beam chops the constant conditions experienced by the qubits down into discrete packets (making the symmetry imposed by the beam a discrete time-translation symmetry). Then
column5: by flipping back and forth at twice the period of the wavelength of the beam
column6: the qubits break with the discrete time-translation symmetry imposed by the laser. They are the first objects we know of that are able to do this.

column1: All of this weirdness makes time crystals rich in new physics
column2: and the control that Sycamore provides researchers beyond other experimental setups could make it an ideal platform for further investigation. That's not to say it cannot be improved
column3: however. Like all quantum systems
column4: Google's quantum computer needs to be perfectly isolated from its environment to prevent its qubits from undergoing a process called decoherence
column5: which eventually breaks down the quantum localization effects
column6: destroying the time crystal. The researchers are working on ways to better isolate their processor and mitigate the impact of decoherence
column7: but it's unlikely they will eliminate the effect for good.

column1: Despite this
column2: Google's experiment is likely to remain the best way to study time crystals for the foreseeable future. Though numerous other projects have succeeded in making what convincingly appear to be time crystals in other ways — with diamonds
column3: helium-3 superfluids
column4: quasiparticles called magnons and with Bose-Einstein condensates (opens in new tab) — for the most part the crystals produced in these setups dissipate too quickly for detailed study.

column1: The theoretical newness of the crystals is in some ways a double-edged sword
column2: as physicists currently struggle to find clear applications for them
column3: although von Keyserlingk has suggested that they could be used as highly accurate sensors. Other proposals include using the crystals for better memory storage or for developing quantum computers with even faster processing power.

column1: But in another sense
column2: the greatest application of time crystals may already be here: They allow scientists to probe the boundaries of quantum mechanics.

column1: It allows you to not just study what shows up in nature
column2: but to actually design it and look at what quantum mechanics lets you do and doesn't let you do
column3: Lazarides said. ""If you don't find something in nature then it doesn't mean it can't exist — we just created one of those things.""";10385;['hdjjmgg'
column4: 'hdja9uq'
column5: 'hdjvci6'

column1: 2;685;eaaffba4c5f53b9a0962c45494864cde9445a0e328778180f8d0e1238fc94f76;posted_link;r/Futurology;https://phys.org/news/2022-07-mathematical-quantum-interstellar-space.html;['vt3f6a'];['criticalbeta37'];[1657148982.0];['Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible'];[nan];2022-07-06;Bob Yirka;Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible;"Mathematical calculations show that quantum communication across interstellar space should be possible

A team of physicists at the University of Edinburgh's School of Physics and Astronomy has used mathematical calculations to show that quantum communications across interstellar space should be possible. In their paper published in the journal Physical Review D
column2: the group describes their calculations and also the possibility of extraterrestrial beings attempting to communicate with us using such signaling.

column1: Over the past several years
column2: scientists have been investigating the possibility of using quantum communications as a highly secure form of message transmission. Prior research has shown that it would be nearly impossible to intercept such messages without detection. In this new effort
column3: the researchers wondered if similar types of communications might be possible across interstellar space. To find out
column4: they used math that describes that movement of X-rays across a medium
column5: such as those that travel between the stars. More specifically
column6: they looked to see if their calculations could show the degree of decoherence that might occur during such a journey.

column1: With quantum communications
column2: engineers are faced with quantum particles that lose some or all of their unique characteristics as they interact with obstructions in their path—they have been found to be quite delicate
column3: in fact. Such events are known as decoherence
column4: and engineers working to build quantum networks have been devising ways to overcome the problem. Prior research has shown that the space between the stars is pretty clean. But is it clean enough for quantum communications? The math shows that it is. Space is so clean
column5: in fact
column6: that X-ray photons could travel hundreds of thousands of light years without becoming subject to decoherence—and that includes gravitational interference from astrophysical bodies. They noted in their work that optical and microwave bands would work equally well.

column1: The researchers noted that because quantum communication is possible across the galaxy
column2: if other intelligent beings exist in the Milky Way
column3: they could already be trying to communicate with us using such technology and we could begin looking for them. They also suggest that quantum teleportation across interstellar space should be possible.";2318;['if5byup'
column4: 'if5gl2q'
column5: 'if6cf69'

column1: 3;565;fd45d6086bd89b013a85e1757f725f7d71c902f0d96eb9e690cf0914d4f46848;posted_link;r/science;https://newatlas.com/physics/new-state-matter-superconductivity-electron-family/;['quc4ce'];['MistWeaver80'];[1636966388.0];['Superconductivity occurs when electrons in a metal pair up. Scientists in Germany have now discovered that electrons can also group together into families of four
column2: creating a new state of matter and potentially a new type of superconductivity and technologies such as quantum sensors.'];[nan];2021-11-08;Michael Irving;"""Electron family"" state of matter hints at new type of superconductivity";"""Electron family"" state of matter hints at new type of superconductivity

column1: Superconductivity occurs when electrons in a metal pair up and move through the material without resistance. But there may be more to the story than we thought
column2: as scientists in Germany have now discovered that electrons can also group together into families of four
column3: creating a new state of matter and
column4: potentially
column5: a new type of superconductivity.

column1: Conductivity is a measure of how easily electrons (and therefore electricity) can move through a material. But even in materials that make good conductors
column2: like gold
column3: electrons will still encounter some resistance. Superconductors
column4: however
column5: remove all such barriers and provide zero resistance at ultracold temperatures.

column1: The reason electrons can move through superconductors so easily is because they pair up through a quantum effect known as Cooper pairing. In doing so
column2: they raise the minimum amount of energy it takes to interfere with the electrons – and if the material is cold enough
column3: its atoms won’t have enough thermal energy to disturb these Cooper pairs
column4: allowing the electrons to flow freely with no loss of energy.

column1: But in the new study
column2: researchers from the Universities of Dresden and Würzburg in Germany made a fascinating discovery. In one particular type of superconductor
column3: they found that Cooper pairs were themselves pairing up
column4: forming families of four electrons.

column1: When we discovered that suddenly four electrons instead of two were forming a bond
column2: we first believed it was a measurement error
column3: ” says Henning Klauss
column4: lead researcher on the study. “But the more methods we used to confirm the result
column5: the clearer it became that this had to be a new phenomenon: all data are consistent with the same result. Now we know that the four particle electron family in certain metals creates a completely new state of matter when cooled to ultra-low temperatures.”

column1: The discovery was made in a superconducting metal containing barium
column2: potassium
column3: iron and arsenic
column4: from a class known as iron pnictides. Such a phenomenon had been theoretically predicted about a decade ago
column5: but no experimental evidence had arisen until now. The researchers then spent two years confirming the find

column1: The team says that these electron families could open a new branch of superconductivity and a range of advanced devices that tap into it. But before then
column2: there’s still plenty of work to be done to unravel how it works
column3: which materials it occurs in
column4: and how it can be invoked.

column1: One can assume that our results will lead to a whole new line of research
column2: looking for other metals with four connected electrons
column3: for example
column4: or exploring how materials need to be changed to create an electron family
column5: says Klauss. ""In purely theoretical terms
column6: a whole new type of superconductivity would also be possible with our electron family. The only thing that is certain is that iron pnictides are well suited for technologies such as quantum sensors due to their new aggregate state.”";3019;['hkp7j9u'
